But we are in a pretty neutral space, which is I think a good outcome for us and the acquisitions that we make and have made serve further to reinforce the strength of the wholesale business.

That business is benefiting from the growing Masters business and the joint buying advantages that those two businesses now get and supplying and increasingly sharing things like supply chains and the like. And we're able to pass on those savings to the customers, which have really been material in the last quarter and I think that's growing the loyalty factor for the Danks customers. So we're confident about that and its performance and its contribution to the Home Improvement space.

In relation to the Dick Smith business and the stores, I guess, you're referring to the reformatted stores, David, that we've referred to and the comp sales that we see in those, they've outperformed the balance of the portfolio of Dick Smith stores now for some time and that's continuing there in the new format they've got the right range and they've traded strongly over the last couple of years, Dave, and they continue to do so. So the positive comp numbers that you saw on the screen for the half come courtesy primarily of those well-performing stores. The reason we're looking at the tail is that they don't perform as well.
So just to clarify the stores, the 100 stores that you're closing, they're the ones that have not been refurbished...
In the main, yes.
And so just on Danks, can you give us or can you quantify what the growth profile was of the underlying Danks business. What's the sales growth there?
I don't have it off the top of my head, David, but we can provide that to you.
Final one for me, if I have a look at your inventory days, you say that excluding the indents, Cellarmasters, et cetera, et cetera, inventory days was down 0.3...
0.1, was it?
Yeah.
Fresh was down a half, I might read into that therefore the dry grocery was up?
Sorry, I missed the bit before dry groceries?
You say that Fresh was down half a day, that you've got half a day of savings in the supply chain on Fresh and therefore does that mean that dry grocery was up? Is that why?

That's one which is a really small or a smallish component of it. So our inventory in supermarkets generally was controlled well. So there is no blow out there that's offset by the half day that Tjeerd was talking about.
Thank you.
The half day relates to time, so you've still got the same level of stock in the stores, it's just getting there quicker.
So we might go to the phones and ask for any questions that we may have online.
Thank you. The first question comes from Phillip Kimber with Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.

Hi, just a question on the sales impact that you're seeing from the deep dive negotiation, I think, you said its over 20% of your sales base now, there is obviously profit impact, but I was more interested in the sales impact?

Good day, Phil, and what Tjeerd was describing is the work that we're undertaking right now and have undertaken over recent months. The benefit from those actions will flow over the course of the next half and the next year. What happens, with the Category Lab is you effectively redesign your shelf space and your category in a store. And what it leads to is a more efficient use of space. It leads to a more sensible mix of product and leads to an improved profit outcome on the shelf. It will take the next little while for that to flow through. We have a very clear idea obviously as a result of the Category Lab process as to what that outcome will be, but I'm not going to point to anything in today's results, because it's too early.

And then follow-on on the hardware losses, are there any costs that come through this fiscal year that are sort of one-off in the sense that they were built up and you capitalized them until you open the first door, they hit this year and you don't get them again next year?

Well, I think the nature of the rollout is exactly that, we'll open 15 stores this year and probably anything up to 18 or 20 the next year. And it's just a continual rollout and we will bear the costs of that in this year and next year and the year after. We said and have said it will take years, three to four for this venture to start to breakeven and as I've said a couple of times, we're on track and so that remains our focus and our expectation.
Thank you. The next question comes from Tom Kierath of Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, just a question on liquor and appreciate Dave's (1:29:38) in there. Strong performance from the liquor division but the share in that business is now almost equal to where it is in supermarkets. Could you just provide some color on I guess where you think that will get to longer term, whether it's ahead of supermarkets?

Our focus is on ensuring that we cover as many shopping occasions for the customers as we can and the market share will be the outcome of that. We're looking to grow our business and we're looking to do that by providing more opportunities for our customers to get the best offers. And I hold liquor up as our best example at multi-option shopping and that was more to come. So we've got well established destination format. We've got well established convenience bricks and mortar formats.

We're completing the integration of our direct and online business courtesy of Cellarmasters. We're growing our online business courtesy of Dan Murphy's. And that's all above line. Then you get the margin benefits that come from being a truly vertically integrated business. So it's one of the most mature models of what we're heading to in other parts of our business. So I think it's an outcome of us winning with the customer. It's not something that we've got written down on the page as an ambition for market share.
Sure, and just another one on private label liquor, you're saying that it's going to double over the next few years. Does that all come from one or should we look at it as beer and spirit as well?

We have a well established label program in wine and that was probably the entry point for us in the liquor space. But increasingly spirits have been added to that and most recently beer in all forms and the fastest growing categories in the liquor areas, as Tony will attest, the ciders and the ginger beer or the alcoholic ginger beers and the like and we're in there early with our own offering, which I think is part and parcel of again why the liquor business has got momentum.

It's not waited until categories become mature and then enter. It's in there early with its own brand and if I could point to low carb beers as an example of that, the Platinum Blonde product that we launch now, two years ago, three years ago, was at the beginning of that growth. So it's across all categories and it's in categories that make sense and categories that we can add value to and choice to for our customers.
Thank you. The next question comes from David Thomas with CLSA. Please go ahead.

Hi guys, I was wondering if it was possible to get a bit more color on the gross margin expansion in the food and liquor side of the Australian food and liquor business. Obviously you did three basis points, including petrol, are you able to give a bit more color on that?

It's a combination of things. Tjeerd touched on one really important one in fact, Tjeerd might get to answer this one, but certainly shrinkage was an important part of that and private label being another part, did you want expand on our margin.

Yeah, it's – what I already alluded to, but it's also because we are increasing our share of global sourcing, so working together with BIG W team and sourcing from Hong Kong, that's significantly more that we've done before. And we've got strong ambitions to grow a direct sourcing together with BIG W in the near future. So it's also growing our own brand share and not our home brand share, but our own brand share, especially Select and Macro which have significant higher margin than the average of the store and I think those three combined gave us a good margin uplift in the half an we're looking forward to see more improvements coming through, but also investing in value.

I think it also goes partway to the question that was asked a moment ago, in relation to Category Lab, Tjeerd, and that is all of those benefits have got to blow through to margin over the coming years that investment in the Category Lab will show itself in margin expansion and top line expansion over the coming years. So there are certainly the suite of things that Tjeerd has spoken about and some of the investments that we're making at the moment.
Thanks, and perhaps one for Tom, the property sale which was about $73 million, did that contribute to EBIT at all?
Property sales, did any of it flow through to EBIT or how much through to EBIT?
No, very small. We normally try and just minimize the lease cost on all our property sales, so we don't really try and get a development profit out of it.
Thank you. The next question comes from Daniel Broeren with RBS. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, I've got a question on supermarkets and the new marketing campaign for the fourth quarter. Can you just talk about how significant the program that might be and also whether it will have a noticeable impact on the cost of doing business in the second half?

The first one is no comment, because we don't want to preempt what's going to be delivered. We spoke about the need for us to lift our game in this space and we're doing that. We're doing it technically at the moment, but in a more profound way will come courtesy of the new agency and resources that Tjeerd is arming himself with. He advised you that he is very close to making his decision in relation to the agency and I know that to be the case and he's being very generous in sharing with you when that program is going to be launched. I'm not going to be any more generous and let you know what it is. But in terms of its cost, we don't expect there to be a material impact on our cost base. These are things that we manage within our, in this case advertising spend and we'll be disciplined enough to make sure that that's the case.

Okay, thank you, and just a question on the cost of doing business in New Zealand. Is the cost increase from the new DC a one-off duplication cost for the transition of DC or is this going to be an ongoing cost that we'll see in the second half as well?

I think you see an increased cost and an increased margin opportunity courtesy of the changes that Dave has made particular in New Zealand, so part of – and it's ongoing and it's steady and it has been for some time. So you've got to cover the cost of the new shed, but they are more than offset by the improvement as you get in margin.
Thank you. The next question comes from Andrew McLennan with CBA. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, I've got a quick question for Tom in relation to the property CapEx. You continue to spend a huge amount of money in the property side, I understand it's going to dilute returns, but could you just explain what kind of impact its having on margins within the supermarkets business for the rental cost your saving?

Well, it will have an impact over time, however we have an interest cost versus a lease cost, so one is going to offset the other. So when you do a property development, you in theory incur or, well, practically incur the interest cost earlier and then obviously you don't have the lease cost, but you do still have the interest cost until you sell it and lease it back.
But that definitely has been captured in the supermarket division rather than elsewhere?

Yeah, we charge – in the corporate center we charge – when a supermarket we own starts trading, we charge the supermarket business a rent which is captured in the offsetting the corporate center. So the supermarket food and liquor result you are seeing is effectively has a rental charge in it.
Thank you. The next question is a follow-up from Phillip Kimber with Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.

Small follow-up question's on the outlook medium term. I think at your strategy day, you mentioned this year's tough and shouldn't expect it to get much better in a profit growth sense in fiscal 2013. Have you seen any change to that since the strategy day?

No, our reconfirmation today of our outlook at that stage is that we're seeing things in a similar sort of ways as we saw at that stage, Phil. Beyond that, we wouldn't make a comment on, so we're not providing guidance on that today. We're reaffirming our guidance for this financial year today.
Okay. Thanks.
Thank you. At this time we're showing no further questions over the phone.

Thank you. Any more questions here? That being the case, can I thank everyone and particularly those that came along today here, thanks guys, appreciate your support and appreciate your questions and look forward to catching up with you afterwards. Thank you.
